title: Nisbet, Alistair, 1958- :"Love the low-rise plan... what's the scale?" ... 13 August 2011
description: Three people stand looking down at a small model of the 'Christchurch CBD'. One of the people says 'Love the safer low-rise plan What's the scale?' A second man says 'Scale? Er this is the actual size!' Context: Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker has dedicated the draft plan for a new-look Christchurch CBD to those lost in the February earthquake. The CBD will be about a quarter of its original size under the draft plan which was unanimously adopted by the council today and there will be a new lower height limit.
Authorities: Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority)

title: Smith, Ashley W, 1948- :[Bob Parker and Jim Anderton]. 20 September 2010
description: Depicts Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker striking a pose under a spotlight while standing astride broken masonry. He is being interviewed by media. On the right of frame, Progressive Party leader and MP Jim Anderton is under dark clouds and caught under the Beehive. Refers to the 2010 Christchurch mayoral elections in which Parker won over Anderton. Prior to the 2010 Canterbury earthquake, Anderton was ahead in the polls. The quake devastation was said to have given Parker a bigger profile than Anderton and been a factor in his win.

title: Evans, Malcolm Paul, 1945- :"The demolition of that hotel is going to take ten MONTHS!" ... 25 May 2011
description:
The barman in a pub is reading a newspaper and comments 'The demolition of that Christchurch Hotel is going to take TEN MONTHS!' A man at a nearby table says to his mate 'I've known footy teams that could do it over a weekend!'
Context - Demolishing the earthquake-crippled Hotel Grand Chancellor could take up to a year, cost more than $10 million and affect about 100 businesses in the drop zone.

title: Bromhead, Peter, 1933-:A tale of two quakes. 16 March 2011

Context - the terrible earthquake and tsunami in Japan 11 March 2011 that have led to the overheating of several nuclear power plants that are leaking radiation and threaten a nuclear catastrophe and the Christchurch earthquake on 22 February 2011 that led to the decision that because of the amount of damage to the venue plus infrastructures and accommodation for visitors the Rugby World Cup will not be played in Christchurch.

Context - When their policies run out on 30 June Earthquake-hit Christchurch and Waimakariri councils are in danger of having no property insurance. There was also a potential problem for home-owners when AMI Insurance, the largest insurer of homes in Christchurch, was threatening insolvency. However, AMI has announced that it has re-insurance cover for earthquakes and other natural disasters from tomorrow (1 July 2011) for the next year.

Context - When their policies run out on 30 June Earthquake-hit Christchurch and Waimakariri councils are in danger of having no property insurance because as the CEO of Civic Assurance, which insures most councils, says, 'the company cannot buy reinsurance'. May also refer to changing insurance regulations after each aftershock.
Authorities: Earthquake insurance claims (subject_authority) # Civic Assurance (name_authority) # Insurance policies (subject_authority) # Insurance (subject_authority)

description: The cartoon is entitled 'seismic upheaval'. Prime Minister John Key and Finance Minister Bill English stand near cracks in the ground and stare sadly at a huge wallet, 'Bill's boodle'. Vast quantities of banknotes spill out and the wallet also contains a 'travel card', a 'house card' and an 'expenses card'. Etched in the ground are the words 'Christchurch quake' and 'South Canterbury Finance', two major events in the Canterbury area that have incurred huge government costs. The South Canterbury Finance Company has been taken into receivership by the government. Treasury is assuming that the cost of the earthquake will reach $4 billion.

description: The cartoon shows two Christchurch airport workers near a newly arrived aircraft which is named Thunderbird 2. Context: More international rescue teams were continuing to arrive in Chrishchurch to assist after the devastating earthquake.

title: Nisbet, Alistair, 1958- :"Dang! I'm busting again!" 16 June 2011
description: A man, half shown, sits on a toilet and says "Dang! I'm busting again!" as he reaches for the toilet paper which has a different 'quake claim' printed on each section. Context - Magnitude 6.0 and 5.5 earthquakes rocked Christchurch again at 1pm and 2.20pm on 13th June 2011. These quakes follow the first earthquake on September 4th 2010 and the second on February 22nd 2011. Each time there is a significant quake more damage is done and so people have to make further insurance claims.

title: Winter, Mark 1958- :SISpicious cracks. 21 July 2011
description: Text reads 'New fault lines?' and the cartoon depicts a Star of David as cracks in the ground. A second version has the text 'Aftershocks' and the cartoon depicts a shaky Star of David and big movements on a seismograph. The third (published) version depicts the same image as the first but has the text 'SISpicious cracks'. Context: The Southland Times reported on 20th July that an Israeli national killed in the February Christchurch Earthquake was a Mossad spy

title: Life in the South Island.. 20 September 2010
description: The cartoon's title is 'Life in the South Island'. A man wonders aloud to his wife when the 'plague of locusts' will arrive as they have had 'collapsing finance companies, earthquakes' and 'heavy snow damage'. Refers to the collapse of South Canterbury Finance, the earthquake of 4th September, and more recently, heavy snow in Southland that has caused roofs to collapse.

title: Nisbet, Alistair, 1958- :"Better ring CERA ... we ain't red or blue ... we're both stuck in the orange zone!" 29 November 2011
description: Depicts Labour MP Brendon Burns and National List MP Nicky Wagner standing in the rubble of the Christchurch central business district (CBD). Burns says 'Better ring CERA...we ain't red or blue...we're both stuck in the orange zone!'. Text: Dead heat in Christchurch Central. Context: Following the 22 February earthquake in Christchurch, Canterbury Earthquake recovery Authority (CERA) divided the city into differently coloured zones determined by severity of land damage. The 2011 General Elections count for the Christchurch Central seat put Burns and Wagner in a dead heat, both polling 10,493 votes. On the recount, the seat went to Nicky Wagner with 12,064 votes.
Authorities: Earthquake damage (subject_authority) # New Zealand Labour Party (name_authority) # New Zealand. Parliament - Elections, 2011 (subject_authority)

title: Nisbet, Alistair, 1958- :Scientists create model to predict quakes...12 January 2012
description: Scientists stand before a model that will predict earthquakes. The model is a large arm attached to wires and switches with a thumb that flicks coins '"Heads" we have big quake at five-o-clock... "tails" we don't'. Context: short term predictions (hours to days) are in general unlikely to be possible, at present. Relates to the Christchurch earthquakes which experts have said could go on for years.
Authorities: Earthquake prediction (subject_authority)

title: WATER... One minute too much... The next, not enough... 8 September 2010
description: Text reads 'Water - One minute too much - The next, not enough' In the first frame a man is fed up with another downpour and in the second frame there is shown a plastic bottle of drinking water. Refers to the amount of rain in recent times but also the need for bottled or boiled water In Canterbury after the earthquake of 4th September 2010 which caused major damage to sewage and water systems.

title: Winter, Mark 1958- :The earth moved ... and so did the government's infrastructure spending estimate. 5 July 2011
description: Text reads 'The earth moved...... and so did the government's infrastructure spending estimate'. Centre cartoon is the text '$17 billion' set against the backdrop of a seismic graph. Authorities: Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Auckland City (place_authority)

description: The cartoon shows rubble and ruined buildings after the Canterbury earthquake of 4th September 2010. Rats representing 'looters' run over the buildings taking advantage as do cockroaches representing 'politics'. title: "In the event of a natural disaster - Harold wants enough provisions to see us through to the Rugby World Cup" 13 September 2010
description: A woman chats over her garden wall to a passerby who is curious about a huge container-like structure labeled 'emergency kit' that has been built beside the house. She says that in the event of a natural disaster Harold wants to ensure that they will have enough provisions to see them through the Rugby World Cup. Context is heightened awareness of earthquake preparedness in the wake of the Christchurch earthquake on 4 September 2010.
Authorities: World Cup (Rugby football) (7th ; 2011 ; New Zealand) (subject_authority) # Survival and emergency equipment (subject_authority)

title: Nisbet, Alistair, 1958- : `The Pop-up Punting Mobile Coffee Shop'. 19 November 2011
description: Cartoon depicts a man and woman relaxing under a beach umbrella while riding a shipping container that is being punted along a polluted river. The container is labeled 'The pop-up punting mobile coffee shop'. Following the devastation to retail buildings in the February 2011 earthquake there have been many 'pop-up' shops appearing, with transitional architecture common, especially those using shipping containers. Also refers to the pollution in Christchurch rivers, including the Avon River, after damage to the city's infrastructure.
Authorities: Business - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Unitized cargo systems (subject_authority)

title: Nisbet, Alistair, 1958-:[Mother Nature cooks up a menu of disasters] 14 January 2011
description: A monster cook who represents 'Mother Nature' stirs several pots as storms swirl outside the window. She has a list of recipes that read 'earthquake entree, tornado twisties, blizzard Bolognese, volcanic mudcake, flood fondue, cyclone souffle'; she says 'Mmmm what shall I cook up next?' Context - the bad weather and the Christchurch earthquake that have afflicted the South Island recently.
Authorities: Natural disasters (subject_authority)

description: In the top frame a man reads a newspaper report that says 'Govt to buy up red stickered homes' and shouts 'That's it - I'm out!' His mate comments that he thought it was his neighbour's house that was munted and that his house was ok. In the lower frame the first man says 'That's right... and I don't want to live next door to a politician?!' Context - A report released 23 June 2011 has divided quake-hit Canterbury into four zones with those in the worst affected residential red zone offered cash to move out. The man in the cartoon thinks that the government is buying up the houses so that politicians can live in them.
Authorities: City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Emergency management (subject_authority) # Earthquake damage (subject_authority) # Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

description: In the first frame a couple read a newspaper with a headline that reads 'Orange Zone delay again' and are frustrated at having to wait yet another two weeks to find out what will happen to their property. They wonder what CERA are doing. In the second frame CERA staff are seen cheering at a Rugby World Cup match. Context: Canterbury Earthquake Recovery Authority (Cera) chief executive Roger Sutton has apologised to more than a 1500 orange-zone homeowners after delaying a decision on rezoning their land.

title: Evans, Malcolm Paul, 1945-:Reserve Bank governor moves to restore confidence after the quake. 11 March 2011

The little Evans man says 'What a relief!' Toilets have been a real problem after the earthquakes with thousands of chemical toilets and portaloos being shipped in. The Reserve Bank has made a relatively large 50-point cut in its benchmark interest rate, the Official Cash Rate (from 3% to 2.5 per cent). The Reserve Bank has chosen to focus on the immediate impact of the earthquake on the economy and particularly on business confidence and consumer sentiment.

title: News- The Lyttleton Port Co. has halted merger talks with Otago since the 'quake, saying 'the landscape has changed'. 6 October 2010
description: An official at the 'Otago Port Co.' stares in bewilderment at the feet of his colleague at the Lyttelton Port Company who says 'Ah, that might do it for now' as he hangs upside down by his feet from his upturned desk in the aftermath of the 4th September Canterbury earthquake. Text above reads 'News, the Lyttelton Port Co. has halted merger talks with Otago since the 'quake, saying "the landscape has changed". Refers to the news that Lyttelton Port, the South Island's biggest port, abandoned two-years of merger talks with rival Port Otago because it is preoccupied with rebuilding after the Canterbury earthquake.

title: Hubbard, James, 1949- :"Look at that flab! Time you had another course in belt tightening!" 1 September 2011
description: The cartoon shows the enormous Earthquake Minister, Gerry Brownlee, ushering a thin 'tax collector' through a door labelled 'Weight losers'. Brownlee says 'Look at all that flab! Time you had another course in belt-tightening! A newspaper lying on the ground has a headline reading 'Govt will look for new revenue in light of $18B quake blowout.' Context: Finance Minister Bill English today revealed fresh estimates put the cost of the Canterbury earthquakes to the Earthquake Commission (EQC) at $7.1 billion - some $4 billion more than earlier believed.
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # New Zealand - Economic conditions (subject_authority)

title: [A sharp reminder to check my emergency survival kit...]
description: A man carries boxes of beer into his living room and tells a woman "What's happened has been a sharp reminder to check my emergency survival kit..."
Authorities: Survival and emergency equipment (subject_authority)

title: [Mayoralty]
description: Shows Mayor of Christchurch Bob Parker climbing a jagged incline with many cracks, as he walks in the direction of a sign labelled 'Mayoralty'. Refers to the mayoralty race in 2015 and how it has been impacted by the Canterbury Earthquake in September 2010.
Authorities: Mayors - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Parker, Robert John (Sir), 1953- (name_authority) # Local elections (subject_authority)

title: [A Mayor like Bob Parker]
description: Shows a couple in an expensive-looking home. The woman says "The people of Christchurch are so lucky" and the man replies "I'll say. What we'd give to have a mayor like Bob Parker". Refers to the mayoral elections in Christchurch in 2015 and the perception that Bob Parker was performing well.
Authorities: Mayors - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Parker, Robert John (Sir), 1953- (name_authority) # Local elections (subject_authority)

title: [Student flat before and after the quake]
description: A two frame cartoon showing an untidy flat before the quake, and then the same room tidied afterwards.
Authorities: Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [earthquake cow]
description: A three-frame gag cartoon of a cow. In the first frame the cow looks up questioningly, before he is shaken violently and loses his markings in the third.
Authorities: Earthquakes (subject_authority)

title: [Quake moves NZ closer to Aust]
description: Shows a group of people in a care home, with a man reading a newspaper with the headline 'Quake moves NZ closwer to Aust'. A woman serves tea and says "Just like Mister Key said he would!"
Authorities: New Zealand - Foreign relations - Australia (subject_authority) # Key, John Phillip (Rt Hon), 1961- (name_authority)

title: [Quake relief donations]
Publisher: Press (Christchurch, N.Z.); Timaru herald (Newspaper); Manawatu standard (Newspaper)
description: A man reads from a newspaper and says that "Donations to quake relief are rolling in!" His son then offers his dinner and says "I'd like to donate my broccoli!"
Authorities: Disaster relief (subject_authority)

title: [The clean-up]
description: Under the heading 'The Clean-up', a digger labelled IRD tries to take a scoop for tax, while other diggers are labelled bank mortgages and bills. On a pile of rubble labelled Christchurch, Bill English is dressed in a high-visibility vest and holds a sign saying 'stop' while shouting "...Wait a minute...!".
Authorities: Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Fiscal policy (subject_authority)

title: [Christchurch Kids]
description: A two frame cartoon, in which a mother bends down to her son and explains "Your Christchurch cousins are coming to stay for a while!" The boy replies they will be "gutted" because "Christchurch kids don't have to go to school!" Refers to the exodus of residents from Christchurch following the September earthquake.

title: [Community]
description: Amongst a broken and moving city, a group of people, labelled community, band together in a hug.
Authorities: Communities (subject_authority)

title: [Photographers]
description: Shows a photographer in front of a building with stickers saying 'safe', 'a bit dodgy' and 'danger!' The photographer has been labelled with a sign saying 'Naff off!' Refers to so-called 'quake tourism' with people coming to view the damage from the September 2010 earthquake.
Authorities: Emergency management (subject_authority)

title: Deep holes need deep pockets
description: A man wearing a tee shirt saying 'give generously New Zealand' reaches into his pockets while standing in a cracked landscape with a broken sign for Canterbury behind him.
Authorities: Charities (subject_authority) # Disaster relief (subject_authority)

title: [Signs of earthquake stress]
description: A principal tells a group of teachers in the staff room "Right - we're to look out for children showing signs of earthquake stress..." He then says "could you stay behind a moment Mr Dobson" as one terrified teacher is wearing a helmet, protective bagging and carrying emergency supplies while clutching on to the room frame.
Authorities: Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority)

title: [Nerves]
description: Shows a man wearing a top labelled Christchurch. A voice asks "It's been a week since the quake... How are your nerves holding up?" The man's head is fractured and crumbling and sections break off suggesting crumbling masonry.
Authorities: Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority)

title: The leaky home owner
Publisher: Timaru herald (Newspaper); Press (Christchurch, N.Z.); Manawatu standard (Newspaper)
description: A three frame cartoon in which a man digs a crack in his yard and paints a crack on his house at night. In the third he waves his arms to draw attention to the claimed earthquake damage.
Authorities: Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Earthquake insurance claims (subject_authority) # Dampness in buildings (subject_authority)

title: Chch Mayoralty. Wigram MP.
description:
Shows Jim Anderton who is MP for Wigram and is standing for Mayor of Christchurch in the 9 October local body elections. Anderton stretches as he tries to keep a foothold in both roles - shown metaphorically as a large 
crack.
Authorities: Local elections (subject_authority) # Mayors - Election (subject_authority) # ON ANOTHER TOPIC

title: History, heritage, heart
description: Shows two badly damaged buildings in a nineteenth-century style, the first labelled history the second labelled heritage. The third is simply the word heart written within a heart shape. Refers to the loss of heritage buildings in Christchurch and Canterbury following the September earthquake.
Authorities: Lost architecture (subject_authority) # Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Local body elections]
description: Two men sit on a park bench, one reading a paper. The first says "Who are the favourites to win the local body elections?" and the second replies "Most voters in most towns seem to be picking Bob Parker!" Refers to the rise in popularity of Christchurch Mayor, Bob Parker, following his high-profile in the wake of the September earthquake.
Authorities: Local elections (subject_authority) # Mayors - Election (subject_authority)

title: Establishing where the fault lies
description: A two part cartoon: in the first half two figures point at the letters SCF as they sink into a large crack. In the second those letters have been dwarfed by an even bigger crack overlooked by two assessors.
Authorities: Finance companies (subject_authority) # Savings and loan association failures (subject_authority) # South Canterbury Finance Ltd (name_authority)

title: [Some places are still uninhabitable]
description: Shows two children seated in slum-like conditions. One says "They say some places are still uninhabitable. Toilets don't work, no water or facilities..." The other replies "- And that's just Christchurch - wait till they get here." Compares the situation in Christchurch after the September earthquake with the conditions in Delhi for the 2010 Commonwealth games.
Authorities: Commonwealth Games (19th ; 2010 ; Delhi, India) (subject_authority) # Public utilities - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Sub-standard living conditions]
description: A two frame cartoon showing two men in conversation, one reading a newspaper. The first reads "Sub-standard living conditions littered with debris - filth and sewage problems - and security issues! We can't expect our athletes to put up with that can we!" The second replies "Athletes! - I thought you were talking about the people of Canterbury!" Compares the situation in Christchurch after the September earthquake with the conditions in Delhi for the 2010 Commonwealth games.
Authorities: Commonwealth Games (19th ; 2010 ; Delhi, India) (subject_authority) # Public utilities - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Refuse and refuse disposal (subject_authority) # Sewerage (subject_authority)

title: "Well, I for one, don't think it's all that great going camping to et away from buildings being shookup with earthquakes!"
description: Shows a man wading through a flooded camping ground. Refers to people on their summer holidays, many trying to 'get away' from aftershocks, who have been hit by heavy rain.
Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority) # Rain and rainfall (subject_authority)

title: [earthquakes]
description: Shows a rollercoaster which has broken through barriers for Sept 4, Dec 26 and Feb 22. Accompanying caption notes that the cartoon was hand-painted at his sister's house by candle-light. Nisbet is quoted as saying "I thought I had to pick myself up and get back to normal".
Authorities: Resilience (Personality trait)

title: [Ian Athfield wants to ban one-way streets]
description: Under a heading that architect Ian Athfield 'wants to ban one-way streets...' a number of cars are shown heading over the Canterbury plains out of town, with one asking "Ban them? But we only need one!" Refers to the numbers of Christchurch residents - so-called 'quake refugees'- choosing to leave the city in the wake of the February 22 earthquake.

title: [Enough]
description: Shows an array of broken masonry with warning tape over the top saying 'Enough Enough Enough...'. Context is the aftershock that hit Christchurch on 13 June 2011, causing further damage.
Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority) # Earthquake damage (subject_authority)

title: [old fashioned earthquake]
description: A couple share photos of their 'grand tour' from a range of places noting that 'now we're home, somehow a good old fashioned earthquake... seems like an old friend!'
Authorities: Earthquakes (subject_authority) # Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority)

title: [The kiwi spirit]
description: Under the heading 'The only thing guaranteed quakeproof...' an arm with a fist is raised between broken buildings. The arm is labelled 'The Kiwi Spirit'. Context is the damage caused by the Christchurch earthquake and national support for the residents.
Authorities: Empathy (subject_authority) # Resilience (Personality trait) # Courage (subject_authority)

title: [Essential building block]
description: A three frame panel, featuring a man with a box for donations. He says: "This is the essential building block needed to reconstruct Christchurch... As yo ucan see, it's rectanble, hollow with a narrow slit on top... To take your generous donation... Thank you!"
Authorities: Charities (subject_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Public buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject authority) # Disaster relief (subject_authority)

title: [Rock for sale]
description: Shows two boys about to push a large boulder down onto a house. The text reads "The kids said they saw where a rock solf for more than our whole house is worth - and they said they'll see if they can beat it. They didn't say how". Refers to a 30-tonne boulder which crashed through a Christchurch house following the earthquake of February 22 2011. The rock was auctioned on Trade Me and fetched over $50,000.

title: [Christchurch economy glue]
description: Shows a figure labelled Auckland tapping the shoulder of John Key who is trying to repair Christchurch with 'economy glue'. Refers to the Government funds required to help with the Christchurch rebuild.
Authorities: Public buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject authority) # Government aid (subject_authority) # Fiscal policy (subject_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Gerry Brownlee]
description: Shows Gerry Brownlee holding a mallet and standing next to a wrecking ball. He says "Right. Let's get cracking and finish what nature intended..." At bottom left a voice says "Ahem, can we grieve and take stock a little, first, Gerry?" Refers to contentious statements allegedly made by Gerry Brownlee with regards to demolishing quake-damaged buildings in Christchurch.
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # Lost architecture (subject_authority)

title: [Leaky buildings]
description: Under the heading 'leaky buildings' a number of people react in fright. They look away from the leaky building elephant and instead point out buildings and structures that are a quake risk or that look shaky.
Authorities: Earthquake resistant design (subject_authority) # Leaky buildings # Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: ['My home town...']
description: Shows two hands reaching towards each other. Also includes a poem beginning and ending: 'My home town has been devastated by a disaster like no other... Our past is in pieces on the ground but now that we have found each other we can honour the dead and together look to the future.'
Authorities: Courage (subject_authority) # Resilience (Personality trait) # Communities (subject_authority)

title: [English and coffers]
description: Shows Finance Minister Bill English walking towards a vault behind which can be seen a smoking crater. English says "The coffers withstood the first quake, I'm curious to know how they fared this time..." Refers to the economic impact of the 22 February earthquake in Christchurch and to that of the earlier quake in September 2010.
Authorities: English, Simon William (Hon), 1961- (name_authority) # Fiscal policy (subject_authority) # Government aid (subject_authority)

title: [earthquake devastation]
description: A man stands at a lectern pointing to a map of Christchurch and Banks Peninsular. He says "The circles are districts devastated by nature. The triangles are areas flattened by Gerry Brownlee."
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # Earthquake damage (subject_authority) # Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Lost architecture (subject_authority)

title: [AMI Stadium red-carded]
description: Under the heading 'AMI Stadium red-carded, it shows an engineer holding up a card as a dejected rugby player walks off. Use a play on red cards and red-stickers to refers to the announcement that no Rugby World Cup matches will be held in Christchurch after AMI stadium suffered extensive damage in the February 22 earthquake.
Authorities: World Cup (Rugby football) (7th ; 2011 ; New Zealand) (subject_authority) # Stadiums - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # AMI Stadium (Christchurch, N.Z.) (name_authority)

title: [His flight was going to Christchurch!]
description: The cartoon shows a large crowd of people stranded in an airport because planes have been grounded by the volcanic eruption in Chile. Most of the people look glum but one man is smiling hugely because 'his flight was going to Christchurch'. Context - Beginning on the 6th of June the Puyehue-Cordon Caulle volcano has been erupting for more than a week. Context also includes two large aftershocks in Christchurch on 13 June 2011.
Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority)

title: [The nation's liquidity]
description: A man labelled 'The Nation's Liquidity' sinks into a pit caused by liquefaction. The pit is labelled 'The bottomless economic liquefaction pit'. Refers to the economic impact of the Christchurch earthquake on the cost to repair the city.
Authorities: Soil liquefaction (subject_authority) # Business - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [New Zealand's wallet hit with powerful aftershock of $8.5b]
description: Under the heading 'New Zealand's wallet hit with personal aftershock of $8.5b' shows a wallet with only IOUs looking worried with faced with the 'Christchurch rebuild'. Refers to the cost of earthquake repairs on the damaged infrastructure of Christchurch.
Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Christchurch suburbs]
description: John Key contemplates a line-up of Christchurch suburbs, one of whom comments "This is like a celebrity chef competition..." Refers to decisions being made around which houses and areas to repair and which to demolish with land reports released in Christchurch.
Authorities: Key, John Phillip (Rt Hon), 1961- (name_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority)

title: [Deja vu]
description: Shows a brick structure labelled Christchurch shaking and crumbling, while asking "How much more deja vu can I take?" Refers to the aftershocks in June 2011 and the anxiety of people in Christchurch.
Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority) # Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Between a rock and a hard place]
description: Shows Gerry Brownlee caught 'Between a rock and a hard place', represented by 'heritage buildings' and 'rebuilding an earthquake-proof Christchurch'. Refers to conflicting demands from heritage advocates and those wanting tighter building regulations for earthquake safety.
Authorities: Lost architecture (subject_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority)

title: [Christchurch lost the World Cup]
description: Shows a hand giving the thumbs down signal with someone saying "Sorry, Christchurch you've lost the World Cup" while another hand gives the thumbs up and says "Hey... but let's keep it in the South Island please!" Refers to the decision to move Rugby World Cup matches out of Christchurch following damage to the city and stadium.
Authorities: Stadiums - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # World Cup (Rugby football) (7th ; 2011 ; New Zealand) (subject_authority)

title: [The aftershocks continue]
description: Under the heading 'The aftershocks continue', shows a man representing New Zealand reacting surprised as he reads a paper headed 'New Insurance Rates'. Refers to increased insurance premiums as a measure to cover the cost of the Canterbury earthquakes.
Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority) # Earthquake insurance claims (subject_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Christchurch travellers]
description: Shows a man labelled Christchurch visiting a travel agent with a sign 'travel the world'. The man says "Actually, where we have in mind is another planet..." Refers to the June aftershock which left many Christchurch residents wanting a 'break'.
Authorities: Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority)

title: [The morale booster]
description: Shows a man representing New Zealand standing on a pile of rubble with a spade. He reaches out a hand to the British crown. Refers to the visit to Christchurch by Prince William.
Authorities: Royal visitors (subject_authority) # Earthquake damage (subject_authority)

title: [What have you got in mind for us?]
description: Shows Prime Minister John Key contemplating the Taj Mahal while man representing 'Chch red zone' asks "While you're contemplating this building treasure, what have you got in mind for us?" Refers to the still unknown plans for the rebuild of central Christchurch, especially the red zone, and links it to Key's 3-day visit to India.
Authorities: Key, John Phillip (Rt Hon), 1961- (name_authority) # Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Lost architecture (subject_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority)

title: [Christchurch's Patience]
description: Shows a large hourglass with Gerry Brownlee in the top half, labelled 'Chch's patience'. Brownlee says "I have a new appreciation for the way subsidence and liquefaction are affecting Cantabrians". Suggests that those impacted by the earthquakes are losing patience, probably with the recovery and rebuild challenges.
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Patience (subject_authority)

title: [A full moon]
description: Shows Ken Ring (the so-called 'Moon Man'). A large moon says "A full moon was once seen as very romantic - not something to be afraid of..." Ring replies "Another head case screwed up by charlatans." Refers to fears held following predictions by Moon that there would be another large earthquake. The fear was most pervasive in Christchurch.
Authorities: Ring, Ken, 194?- (name_authority) # Earthquake prediction (subject_authority)

title: [The bail-out man]
description: Shows Prime Minister John Key balancing a bucket labelled 'AMI insurance' on his head and carrying buckets labelled 'South Canterbury Finance' and 'Chch' and heading towards a sign pointed 'going south'. Refers to those two financial failures and the costs of the Christchurch earthquakes.
Authorities: Key, John Phillip (Rt Hon), 1961- (name_authority) # AMI Insurance (name_authority) # Savings and loan association failures (subject_authority) # Finance companies (subject_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Christchurch settlements...]
description: Under the heading 'Christchurch settlements' shows a large block next to a rock. A voice between them asks "So, which is the rock and which is the hard place, Gerry?" Probably refers to decisions to be made around designating some houses rebuild and others to be demolished with land reports due. A range of outcomes are wanted from home-owners.
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority)

title: [Serious planking]
description: Shows a man labelled 'Re-building Christchurch' planking between two rocks. The heading reads 'Serious planking...' and the text below reads 'one-in-four chance of another big earthquake'. Compares seismologists' predictions and the popularity of 'planking' amongst some people to stress the precariousness of the situation in Christchurch.
Authorities: Earthquake prediction (subject_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority)

title: [Irish workers to help rebuild Christchurch?]
description: Under the heading 'Irish workers to help rebuild Christchurch?' shows builders who have built a house upside down because "we're down under now!" A number of Irish workers, especially builders, have temporarily relocated to Christchurch to help with the rebuild.
Authorities: Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Brownlee Tailors]
description: Shows man representing 'Chch recovery pkge' wearing a suit that is too small. His tailor, Gerry Brownlee says "It fits, that's blindingly obvious". A signboard advertises 'Brownlee Tailors - fits to suit'. Refers to public opinion about the funding of the Christchurch rebuild and the choice of priority projects.
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Government aid (subject_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Reality checks...]
description: A two-frame cartoon with the heading 'Reality checks'. IN the first man labelled Christchurch is faced with two arms, one giving the thumbs down sign and one holding a sign reading 'Chch CBD to lose 900 buildings'. In the second a man labelled Auckland is faced with two arms, one giving a fingers crossed sign and the other holding a sign reading '393 earthquake-prone buildings listed.' Comments on lessons learned on earthquake preparedness in the wake of the Christchurch earthquakes.
Authorities: Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Lost architecture (subject_authority) # Earthquake resistant design (subject_authority) # Auckland City (place_authority)

title: [Redzone not Fanzone]
description: Shows a group of angry people with placards saying 'Get in behind!' 'Come on deadbeats' etc Some explains "Forget 'Fanzone'... This is 'Redzone!' Everyone here cheers on their insurance company!" Refers to the Rugby World Cup Fanzone for watching the tournament, and to increasing frustration with insurance companies dealing with earthquake claims.
Authorities: World Cup (Rugby football) (7th ; 2011 ; New Zealand) (subject_authority) # Earthquake insurance claims (subject_authority) # Insurance companies (subject_authority)

title: [Brownlee and bulldozer]
description: Shows Gerry Brownlee driving a bulldozer amongst debris while Godzilla looks on adoringly and says "I just have to tell you, Gerry - I LOVE your work". Refers to Brownlee's attitude towards demolishing buildings in Christchurch following the earthquake.
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Lost architecture (subject_authority)

title: "The bin!... not the portaloo!" 25 September 2010
description: The small crane on the back of a rubbish truck has picked up a whole portaloo and dumped its contents (a man with his pants around his ankles) into the rubbish. The driver tells the crane operator that he should have emptied "the bin! ... Not the portaloo!" A streetsign reads 'Avonside'. Refers to the use of portaloos in parts of Christchurch since the earthquake of 4th September because of damage to plumbing infrastructure.
Authorities: Portable toilets (subject_authority) # Sewerage (subject_authority) # Public utilities - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [NZ in debt]
description: Shows two figures representing New Zealand up to their necks in debt. One says "Aren't you glad we're not in Christchurch, up to yer knees in silt..." Christchurch suffered further liquefaction following the aftershocks on 23 December 2011.
Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority) # Soil liquefaction (subject_authority) # Infrastructure (Economics) - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Losing Power]
description: A four-frame cartoon in which John Key speaks to Simon Power (minister for everything). Key explains that it's hard to take an unexpected hit like this and that "Losing Power means everything is more difficult" "Nothing runs as smoothly, and you plunge into despair". In the final frame he says "So I know what people in Christchurch must be feeling". Refers to the resignation of National minister Simon Power and the situation for those in Christchurch - many of whom have been without electricity since the earthquake.
Authorities: Key, John Phillip (Rt Hon), 1961- (name_authority) # Public utilities - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority)

title: [Ken Ring]
description: Shows astrologer Ken Ring (the so-called 'Moon man') leaving TV3. Henny Penny says "Don't listen to John Campbell. You just have to put the information out and let people decide for themselves." The chicken is joined by the boy who cried wolf and a man holding a sign saying 'the end is near!!' Refers to the prophecies of Ken Ring, who has said there will be more earthquakes.
Authorities: Ring, Ken, 194?- (name_authority) # Earthquake prediction (subject_authority) # Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Campbell, John James, 1964- (name_authority)

title: Moreu, Michael
description: Shows two children picking up their Christmas presents. In the second and third frames they are shaken. In the fourth they say "Are you sure it isn't cheating if we have help from above?" Refers to children shaking their presents to find out what they are, but links this with the pre-Christmas earthquake in Christchurch.
Authorities: Christmas (subject_authority)

title: [Marryatt's pay rise]
description: A two panel cartoon: in the first panel man reads from a newspaper "All that money to prop up that controversial, crusty old relic!" A woman replies "Cathedral repairs?" He then says "Marryatt's pay rise" Refers to public perceptions of the expenditure in Christchurch, including on the Anglican Cathedral and on the pay of Tony Marryatt.
Authorities: Marryatt, Tony, 1966- (name_authority) # Christchurch Cathedral (Christchurch, N.Z.) (name_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Christchurch (N.Z.). City Council (name_authority)

title: [No more disasters]
description: Shows a man labelled 'South Island' opening the door to a child labelled '2012'. The man says "Please... no more disasters, earthquakes or floods..." Refers to the succession of events in the South Island in 2011 and hopes for a better year in 2012.
Authorities: Disasters (subject_authority)

title: [Two purple cakes]
description: Shows two cupcakes labelled Haiti and Christchurch. Heading reads 'Not one, but two purple cakes...'

title: [For Canterbury]
description: Under the heading 'For Canterbury', shows a hand lighting a candle. Refers to hope for the victims of the Christchurch earthquake.
Authorities: Courage (subject_authority)

title: [Ken Ring]
description: A monster disguised as Ken Ring (the Moon Man) holds a notice labelled 'earthquake predictions' outside a couple's room. The two people huddle in their bed in fear. Refers to the predictions of another large earthquake by Ring, and the impact it has had on many people, especially the residents of Christchurch.
Authorities: Ring, Ken, 194?- (name_authority) # Earthquake prediction (subject_authority) # Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority)

title: [Driver caught in Lyttelton tunnel]
description: A terrified driver is heading towards the end of a tunnel. Text at top reads: A Rakaia truck driver was caught in the Lyttelton Road tunnel during last week's quake. The driver says "It may be shaky... but there's a light at the end of the tunnel and I'm aiming for it!" A footnote says 'Hope all those suffering can do likewise'. Refers to the February 22 earthquake in Christchurch.
Authorities: Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Courage (subject_authority) # Roads - Earthquake effects (subject_authority)

title: [Save Northland Rail]
description: Text at top reads 'The 'Save Northland Rail' group says it 'has the ears' of several politicians'. A rail worker shows a couple a number of ears in a display case and says "These closed-off ones are Gerry Brownlee's and were donated by the people of Christchurch". Refers to the campaign to save rail and to the perception that Gerry Brownlee is not listening to the wishes of the residents of Christchurch regarding the city's rebuild.
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # Politicians - New Zealand - Public opinion (subject_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority)

title: [Grand plan for Christchurch]
description: Shows a figure labelled Christchurch sitting by a signpost pointing to limbo, angst, deja vu and Catch 22. The post is broken and held together with no. 8 wire. The figure asks John Key and Gerry Brownlee "So, what's the grand plan for a basket case?"
Authorities: Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Key, John Phillip (Rt Hon), 1961- (name_authority) # Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority)

title: [Prince William visits Christchurch]
description: Shows an elderly couple having a cup of tea. The woman says "I'm so glad Prince William took time out to visit Christchurch" and the man replies "Not much talk about becoming a Republic lately".

title: [Another 5.0]
description: Shows two seismologists as a quake strike. One says "Whoa, another 5.0 where did that one come from?" The other reads the print out and says "The hordes of angry people stamping their feet outside Tony Marryatt's office."

description: Shows Gerry Brownlee suspended in an hourglass filled with sand labelled 'Chch's patience'. Brownlee says "I have a new appreciation for the way subsidence and liquefaction are affecting Cantabrians..."

title: [Building frames]
description: A man stands in front of two buildings buttressed with zimmer frames and explains "I got the idea from my Grandma". The other man replies that it "really adds to the city's cultural complexity". Context is earthquake damage to heritage buildings in Christchurch.
Authorities: Buildings - Earthquake effects (subject_authority) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Earthquake resistant design (subject_authority)

title: Scott, Thomas, 1947- :[Christchurch earthquake] 25 February 2011
description: From 'The best of Tom Scott' from 2011. The cartoon shows a digger dredging through the rubble and digging up a red heart representing 'hope' (Tom Scott doesn't use colour so this is significant). A rescuer nearby yells 'Careful! It's still beating'. Context is the earthquake on 22 February 2011. There were many people trapped in collapsed buildings, with people holding out hopes of late rescues.

title: Winter, Mark 1958-: Christchurch 'Silly' Council... 28 January 2012
description: Two versions relate to news that an independent government representative has been appointed to help improve the Christchurch City Council, where problems have been apparent for several months, and there have been recent calls for staff to be replaced by commissioners. [not the primary version on NL]
Authorities: Christchurch (N.Z.). City Council (name_authority)

title: [Kiwi thinks of Christchurch]

title: [Enough! Enough!]
description: Shows the figure of Christchurch with a seismograph recording movement. The figure anxiously says 'Enough! Enough!' Refers to ongoing aftershocks in Christchurch.
Authorities: Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority)

title: [Rebuilding Christchurch Lucky Dip]
description: Shows a man labelled 'rebuilding Chch' reaching into the 'Chch city council "basket case"' for a lucky dip. Context is disfunctionality within the Christchurch City Council and allegations of a 'lottery' aspect to elements of the rebuild process, including zoning decisions.
Authorities: Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Bureaucracy (subject_authority) # Christchurch (N.Z.). City Council (name_authority)

title: [Stop shaking!]
description: Shows a man standing for Christchurch citizens precariously balanced between the backs of the of the 'Chch Council's Chief Executive' and 'The Chch City Council'. He says "I wish everything would stop shaking". Context is discontent within and towards the Christchurch City Council and its Chief Executive Tony Marryatt. Also refers to ongoing aftershocks in the region.
Authorities: Marryatt, Tony, 1966- (name_authority) # Christchurch (N.Z.). City Council (name_authority)

title: [Earthquake predictions]
description: In an interior labelled 'Earthquake predictions', a person looks into a crystal ball and tells a man "You will get a jolt on hearing my fees - followed by a series of aftershocks".
Authorities: Earthquake prediction (subject_authority)

title: [Remember Christchurch]
description: Shows a group of people in a church to 'remember Christchurch'. One man is missing an arm and a leg, and says "Miraculously, I survived the quake totally unscathed. Then twelve months later, the insurance company took a couple of limbs."
Authorities: Christchurch Earthquake, N.Z., 2011 - Anniversaries, etc. (subject_authority) # Earthquake insurance claims (subject_authority)

title: [The Human Spirit and the Path Forward]
description: Under the heading 'Rebuilding Christchurch' shows man walking along a path labelled 'The human spirit' walking in the direction of 'The path forward'. Refers to the state of the Christchurch rebuild, two years after the February earthquake.
Authorities: Resilience (Personality trait) # Buildings - Repair and reconstruction - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # City planning - New Zealand - Canterbury Region (subject_authority) # Courage (subject_authority) # Christchurch Earthquake, N.Z., 2011 - Anniversaries, etc. (subject_authority)

title: [Why do we have earthquakes?]
description: Shows two boys walking along. The first asks "Why do we have earthquakes?" and the other replies "Someone said it was God's will". In the next frame the boy then asks "Did God die and leave a will?" and is answered "No - he works in mysterious ways!" In the third frame he says "Like our house did?" and the older boy replies "yeah!" In the final frame the small boy asks "Has anyone burnt any bibles?" and the older replies "not yet". Context is attempts to understand the earthquakes in Christchurch.

title: [Christmas gets heavier in the south]
description: Shows a Christmas tree labelled 'mainland' drooping under the weight of 'Quakes' 'Snow' and 'SCF'. An opened present reveals Pike River. Refers to the range of disasters in the South Island in 2011.
Authorities: Snow - New Zealand (subject_authority) # Savings and loan association failures (subject_authority) # South Canterbury Finance Ltd (name_authority)

title: [Aftershock rattles Christchurch]
description: A shop owner tells a passing woman "We've been using the same news billboard for the past twelve months." The billboard reads 'Aftershock rattles Christchurch'. Refers to the seeming endless series of aftershocks in that city.
Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority)

title: [When does this ride end?]
description: Shows a row of people on a thrill-ride as it's spinning. One woman asks "When does this ride end??" and a child replies "This is Christchurch... it doesn't..." Uses quake humour to comment on the seemingly relentless aftershocks in the city.
Authorities: Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority)

title: [Some real jobs for Marryatt]
description: Under the heading 'Some REAL jobs for Marryatt to justify his salary?...' a series of vignettes has Tony Marryatt being used to hang helmets, provide foundations, repairing phone connections, weather-proofing roofs, as a road cone and as fence bracing. Context is controversy over the pay rise afforded to Christchurch City Council CEO Tony Marryatt.
Authorities: Marryatt, Tony, 1966- (name_authority) # Local government (subject_authority) # Merit pay (subject_authority)

title: [Rebuilding Christchurch, apology]
description: Shows a clown labelled Christchurch City Council swamped by 'government brickbats'. Gerry Brownlee says "And this apology might ease the pain". Refers to reported comments by Gerry Brownlee in which he called Christchurch Mayor Bob Parker a 'clown'.
Authorities: Brownlee, Gerard Anthony (Hon), 1956- (name_authority) # Parker, Robert John (Sir), 1953- (name_authority)

title: [Insurance companies and seismic activity]
description: A woman at the Council Customer Service Centre hands a man his LIM report. He asks about a map and she says "Yeah, you might like that too - it's a map of insurance companies whose policies are at risk of contorting after sever seismic activity." A spider comments "It's called insurance not assurance!"
Authorities: Earthquake insurance claims (subject_authority)

title: [Nocturnal earthquake precautions]
description: Shows a couple and their cat tightly strapped into their bed. The woman asks "So, how much longer do take nocturnal earthquake precautions?" Context is aftershocks in Christchurch and ongoing psychological impact.
Authorities: Disasters - Psychological aspects (subject_authority) # Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority)

description: Shows a hand circling a classified ad. The ad reads ' Due to implosion exclusive club seeks new member! Only dysfunctional, secretive, self-serving, inarticulate individuals need apply' Says to send CVs to Burwood Ward for the Christchurch City Council Club.

title: [Emmerson weekly round-up]

Authorities: Earthquake aftershocks (subject_authority)

title: [the earth moved]
description: Shows a house that has partially collapsed. From inside a voice says "Wow, did the earth move for you too dear?" Context is a joking sexual reference to the Canterbury earthquake
